extraction_metadata.title: No-take marine reserves consistently generate larger conservation benefits than fished areas

entities_extracted.description: Global meta-analysis of no-take reserve effects on fish biomass

notake_vs_fished.interpretation: 170% more fish biomass in no-take reserves

entities_extracted.source_quote: Fish biomass was on average 2.7 times higher in no-take reserves compared to fished areas

entities_extracted.description: Temporal patterns of biomass recovery in reserves

initial_response_years.notes: Significant biomass increase detectable after 5 years

continued_growth.observation: Some reserves show continued growth >20 years

entities_extracted.source_quote: Recovery trajectories suggest reserves require 10-20 years to reach maximum biomass

size_effect.interpretation: Larger reserves show modestly better outcomes

entities_extracted.source_quote: Reserve performance was most strongly associated with enforcement and age

entities_extracted.definition: Classification of MPAs by fishing restrictions

no_take.definition: Complete prohibition on all extractive activities

lightly_protected.definition: Some gear restrictions but commercial fishing allowed

entities_extracted.source_quote: Protection level is the strongest predictor of conservation outcomes

entities_extracted.description: Compilation of MPA effectiveness studies for meta-analysis

relationships_extracted.subject: no_take_status
relationships_extracted.source_quote: No-take reserves consistently outperform partially protected areas

relationships_extracted.subject: enforcement_level
relationships_extracted.quantification: 2.3x difference between well and poorly enforced
relationships_extracted.mechanism: Prevents illegal fishing and maintains protection

relationships_extracted.subject: reserve_age
relationships_extracted.quantification: 1.7x difference between old and young reserves
relationships_extracted.mechanism: Time for population recovery and trophic restoration

bridge_axiom_support.notes: Updated synthesis confirming and refining Edgar 2014 NEOLI findings

key_quotes.quote: Fish biomass was on average 2.7 times higher in no-take reserves compared to fished areas, with the strongest effects observed for targeted species (3.4×) and apex predators (4.2×)
Enforcement emerged as the strongest predictor of reserve performance, with well-enforced reserves showing biomass ratios more than double those of poorly enforced reserves
Our results provide updated and more precise estimates that can inform the design and management of marine protected areas globally

provenance.confidence_assessment: high - rigorous meta-analysis with large sample size
